questions.question: What is the goal of selecting switching and routing protocols?

options.text: To minimize the number of switches and routers used in a network.
To choose protocols that best match a customer’s business goals and technical requirements.
To always select vendor-proprietary protocols for better performance.
To reduce cabling costs by limiting network scalability.

questions.explanation: Protocol selection must align with both business objectives and technical requirements so that the resulting network design is scalable, reliable, and fit for purpose.

questions.question: Why is protocol selection important in network design?

options.text: It determines the color-coding and labeling of cables.
It ensures scalability, reliability, and performance while helping select the most appropriate switch or router.
It eliminates the need for documentation and testing.
It guarantees zero latency across the network.

questions.explanation: Choosing the right protocols helps ensure the network can grow, perform well, and remain reliable while matching hardware capabilities to design goals.

questions.question: What systematic process is recommended for protocol selection?

options.text: Using trial-and-error testing in a production network.
Selecting protocols based solely on vendor popularity.
Using decision tables that match protocols to business and technical goals.
Choosing the newest protocol available.

questions.explanation: Decision tables provide a structured way to compare protocol features against business and technical requirements, improving design decisions.

questions.question: What is a switching protocol?

options.text: A protocol that controls how Layer 2 switches forward frames and avoid loops.
A protocol used only for assigning IP addresses.
A protocol that encrypts data at the application layer.
A protocol used exclusively for WAN routing.

questions.explanation: Switching protocols operate at Layer 2 and define how frames are forwarded while preventing loops in switched networks.

questions.question: What is a routing protocol?

options.text: A protocol that allows routers to dynamically learn and exchange network reachability information.
A protocol that tags Ethernet frames with VLAN IDs.
A protocol that prevents Layer 2 loops.
A protocol used only for physical media selection.

questions.explanation: Routing protocols enable routers to discover networks and share reachability information dynamically.

questions.question: What is Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)?

options.text: A Layer 3 protocol used to calculate shortest paths.
A Layer 2 protocol documented in IEEE 802.1D that prevents loops by creating a loop-free tree topology.
A VLAN management protocol.
A routing protocol for large internetworks.

questions.explanation: STP operates at Layer 2 and prevents switching loops by logically pruning redundant paths into a loop-free tree.

questions.question: Why are loops dangerous in Layer 2 networks?

options.text: They reduce available bandwidth slightly.
They cause broadcast storms, duplicate frames, and MAC table instability.
They slow down routing convergence only.
They only affect wireless networks.

questions.explanation: Layer 2 loops can create broadcast storms and unstable MAC tables, severely impacting network operation.

questions.question: What is a root bridge in STP?

options.text: The switch with the highest bandwidth interfaces.
The central reference switch from which the spanning tree is built.
Any switch connected to end devices.
The switch with the most VLANs configured.

questions.explanation: The root bridge is the logical center of the spanning tree and serves as the reference point for path calculations.

questions.question: How is the root bridge elected in STP?

options.text: By selecting the switch with the lowest Bridge ID.
By selecting the switch with the highest MAC address.
By administrator manual selection only.
By selecting the switch with the most ports.

questions.explanation: STP elects the root bridge based on the lowest Bridge ID, which is composed of priority and MAC address.

questions.question: What is a VLAN?

options.text: A physical separation of switches using dedicated cabling.
A logical emulation of a LAN that groups devices into an administrative domain.
A routing protocol used inside an autonomous system.
A WAN technology for long-distance communication.

questions.explanation: A VLAN logically groups devices regardless of physical location, improving management, security, and broadcast control.

questions.question: What is a trunk link?

options.text: A link between switches that carries traffic for multiple VLANs.
A link used only for management traffic.
A point-to-point WAN connection.
A backup link used only during failures.

questions.explanation: Trunk links allow multiple VLANs to traverse a single physical link between switches using VLAN tagging.

questions.question: What standard defines VLAN tagging?

options.text: IEEE 802.3
IEEE 802.11
IEEE 802.1Q
RFC 2328

questions.explanation: IEEE 802.1Q defines how VLAN information is added to Ethernet frames on trunk links.

questions.question: What is the main goal of a routing protocol?

options.text: To share network reachability information among routers.
To prevent Layer 2 loops.
To tag frames with VLAN IDs.
To assign MAC addresses to devices.

questions.explanation: Routing protocols allow routers to learn about networks and determine how to reach them efficiently.

questions.question: What is convergence in routing?

options.text: The time it takes to install new cabling.
The process by which all routers agree on optimal routes after a change.
The calculation of VLAN IDs.
The selection of a root bridge.

questions.explanation: Convergence describes how quickly routers reach a consistent view of the network after topology changes.

questions.question: What is a distance-vector routing protocol?

options.text: A protocol where routers share routing tables with neighbors periodically.
A protocol that sends updates only when changes occur.
A protocol based on a full topology database.
A protocol used only between autonomous systems.

questions.explanation: Distance-vector protocols exchange routing information periodically and base decisions on distance metrics.

questions.question: What algorithm do link-state routing protocols use?

options.text: Bellman-Ford algorithm.
Flooding algorithm.
Dijkstra’s Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm.
Round-robin scheduling.

questions.explanation: Link-state protocols use Dijkstra’s SPF algorithm to compute the shortest paths through the network graph.

questions.question: What is RIP?

options.text: A link-state routing protocol using cost as a metric.
A simple distance-vector routing protocol using hop count.
A proprietary Cisco enhanced routing protocol.
An exterior routing protocol used on the Internet.

questions.explanation: RIP is a basic distance-vector protocol that uses hop count as its sole routing metric.

questions.question: What is the maximum hop count in RIP?

options.text: 10 hops.
15 hops.
30 hops.
255 hops.

questions.explanation: RIP limits paths to a maximum of 15 hops, which restricts its scalability.

questions.question: What is OSPF?

options.text: An open-standard link-state routing protocol defined in RFC 2328.
A distance-vector protocol using hop count.
A proprietary VLAN tagging protocol.
An exterior routing protocol used only by ISPs.

questions.explanation: OSPF is an open-standard link-state protocol designed for scalable and fast-converging networks.

questions.question: What is the key takeaway for switching and routing design?

options.text: Always choose the simplest protocol regardless of requirements.
Choose protocols that balance scalability, performance, convergence, and administrative control.
Avoid open standards whenever possible.
Design networks without considering business goals.

questions.explanation: Effective switching and routing design requires balancing technical performance with scalability and administrative needs.
